title: Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election
deleted: ===Gaza war protest movements===
{{main|Gaza war protest vote movements}}

The [[Gaza war protest vote movements]] began as movements targeting Biden's policy towards the Gaza war. After an "uncommitted" vote in the US state of Michigan, activists sought to replicate the protest in other US states. A parallel Abandon Biden movement grew urging Biden to drop out of the presidential race.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gangitano |first=Alex |date=February 19, 2024 |title=Michigan progressives angry over Gaza urge voters to ditch Biden in primary |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/4471290-michigan-progressives-gaza-biden-primary/ |access-date=March 3, 2024 |website=The Hill}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last1=Stepansky |first1=Joseph |last2=Silmi |first2=Malak |title=Birth of a Movement: Michigan's Arab voters rise up to challenge Biden |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/longform/2024/2/27/birth-of-a-movement-michigans-arab-voters-rise-up-to-challenge-biden |access-date=March 3, 2024 |website=Al Jazeera |archive-date=March 3, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240303120830/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/longform/2024/2/27/birth-of-a-movement-michigans-arab-voters-rise-up-to-challenge-biden |url-status=live }}</ref> The uncommitted vote was the largest opposition to the [[Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign]] and received higher vote totals than many contenders in the [[2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries]], including [[Amy Klobuchar]], [[Cory Booker]], [[Beto O'Rourke]], and Biden's vice president [[Kamala Harris]]. Uncommitted votes also achieved a higher percentage of the vote than the 2020 campaign of [[Pete Buttigieg]], with only a fraction of the spending.<ref name=UncommittedResults>{{cite magazine|last=Nichols|first=John|title=What the "Uncommitted" Campaign Has Already Won|date=June 10, 2024|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/politics/uncommitted-primary-total-results-biden/|magazine=The Nation|access-date=July 25, 2024|archive-date=June 14, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240614163924/https://www.thenation.com/article/politics/uncommitted-primary-total-results-biden/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Biden received 81.1% of the vote in [[2024 Michigan Democratic presidential primary|Michigan]], with "[[None of These Candidates]]" and "[[Uncommitted (voting option)|uncommitted]]" coming in second in each state, respectively. On March 5 ("Super Tuesday"), he won 15 of 16 primaries, netting 80% or more of the vote in 13 of them.<ref>{{Cite web |title=2024 U.S. Election – Latest News and Updates on Presidential and State Races |url=https://www.yahoo.com/election/ |publisher=Yahoo! |access-date=July 21, 2024 |archive-date=July 20, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240720155834/https://www.yahoo.com/election/ |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=March 5, 2024 |title=Super Tuesday Results: Key Races to Watch |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/03/05/us/elections/results-super-tuesday-key-races.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=July 21, 2024 |archive-date=May 30, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240530060536/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/03/05/us/elections/results-super-tuesday-key-races.html |url-status=live}}</ref> On March 12, Biden reached more than the 1,968 delegates needed to win the Democratic nomination, becoming the presumptive nominee.<ref>{{cite news |last=Schneider |first=Elena |date=March 12, 2024 |title=Biden officially clinches Democratic nomination for president |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2024/03/12/biden-cllinches-democratic-presidential-nomination-00146648 |newspaper=Politico |access-date=July 21, 2024 |archive-date=May 10, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240510165308/https://www.politico.com/news/2024/03/12/biden-cllinches-democratic-presidential-nomination-00146648 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last1=Yoon |first1=Robert |last2=Sweedler |first2=Maya |date=March 12, 2024 |title=How Biden won enough delegates for another Democratic presidential nomination |url=https://apnews.com/article/biden-democrats-nomination-president-delegate-34a06d45d909c077fbeed17014f92986 |access-date=May 11, 2024 |publisher=Associated Press |archive-date=May 11, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240511085623/https://apnews.com/article/biden-democrats-nomination-president-delegate-34a06d45d909c077fbeed17014f92986 |url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election
deleted: ===International response===

'''{{flag|Australia}}''': Prime Minister [[Anthony Albanese]] praised Biden, saying he "has presided over an economy that has seen jobs grow, that has seen wages increase, and that has seen the transition proceed that is occurring as the world moves towards net zero. As well as he's standing up on issues such as [[gender equality]]. President Biden has been a great friend of Australia and that will continue",<ref name="Reuters-2024">{{Cite web |date=July 22, 2024 |title=Biden withdraws from campaign: How foreign leaders are reacting |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us/how-foreign-leaders-reacted-biden-dropping-out-white-house-race-2024-07-21/ |access-date=July 22, 2024 |work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> also stating that the "Australia–US Alliance has never been stronger with our shared commitment to democratic values, international security, economic prosperity and climate action for this and future generations".<ref name="q282">{{cite web |last=Gualtieri |first=Allison Elyse |date=July 21, 2024 |title=Foreign leaders react to Biden's decision not to seek reelection |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/foreign-leaders-react-to-biden-withdrawal-starmer-tusk-harris-herzog/ |access-date=July 22, 2024 |website=[[CBS News]] |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722050328/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/foreign-leaders-react-to-biden-withdrawal-starmer-tusk-harris-herzog/ |url-status=live}}</ref>

'''{{flag|Brazil}}''': President [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]] said of Biden, "Only he could decide whether or not he would be a candidate" and "...Brazil's relationship will be with whoever is elected".<ref>{{Cite web |date=July 22, 2024 |title=Lula comenta desistência de Biden: 'Somente ele poderia decidir se iria ou não ser candidato' |trans-title=Lula comments on Biden's withdrawal: 'Only he could decide whether or not he would be a candidate' |url=https://g1.globo.com/politica/noticia/2024/07/22/lula-comenta-desistencia-de-biden-e-diz-esperar-que-democratas-escolham-um-bom-candidato-substituto.ghtml |access-date=July 22, 2024 |website=G1 |language=pt-br |archive-date=July 23, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240723020926/https://g1.globo.com/politica/noticia/2024/07/22/lula-comenta-desistencia-de-biden-e-diz-esperar-que-democratas-escolham-um-bom-candidato-substituto.ghtml |url-status=live }}</ref>

'''{{flag|Canada}}''': Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] said: "I've known President Biden for years. He's a great man, and everything he does is guided by his love for his country. As President, he is a partner to Canadians—and a true friend. To President Biden and the First Lady: thank you".<ref name="q995" /><ref name="VOA-2024">{{Cite web |first=Nike |last=Ching |date=July 21, 2024 |title=Foreign leaders react to Biden dropping White House bid |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/foreign-leaders-react-to-biden-dropping-white-house-bid/7707094.html |access-date=July 22, 2024 |website=Voice of America |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722102750/https://www.voanews.com/a/foreign-leaders-react-to-biden-dropping-white-house-bid/7707094.html |url-status=live}}</ref>

'''{{flag|China}}''': At a regular press briefing on July 22, the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson [[Mao Ning (diplomat)|Mao Ning]] declined to comment, and said the "presidential election is an internal affair of the United States".<ref name="t904">{{cite web |last=Yang |first=William |title=Biden's decision to bow out goes viral on Chinese social media |website=Voice of America |date=July 22, 2024 |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/biden-s-decision-to-bow-out-goes-viral-on-chinese-social-media-/7707721.html |access-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722125146/https://www.voanews.com/a/biden-s-decision-to-bow-out-goes-viral-on-chinese-social-media-/7707721.html |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="n013">{{cite web |date=July 22, 2024 |title=拜登退选 中方回应 |trans-title=Biden withdraws from the election, China responds |url=http://www.chinanews.com.cn/gn/2024/07-22/10255122.shtml |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722125605/http://www.chinanews.com.cn/gn/2024/07-22/10255122.shtml |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |access-date=July 22, 2024 |website=China News Network - Comprehensive world news |language=zh}}</ref>

'''{{flag|Czech Republic}}''': Prime Minister [[Petr Fiala]] stated: "It is undoubtedly the decision of a statesman who has served his country for decades. It is a responsible and personally difficult step, but it is all the more valuable. I am keeping my fingers crossed for the USA that a good president emerges from the democratic competition of two strong and equal candidates".<ref name="Reuters-2024" /><ref name="q282" />

'''{{flag|France}}''': In a letter, President [[Emmanuel Macron]] praised Biden's "courage, spirit of responsibility and sense of duty that led [him] to this decision".<ref>{{Cite web |date=July 22, 2024 |title=Présidentielle américaine 2024 : Emmanuel Macron salue le "courage" et le "sens du devoir" de Joe Biden |url=https://www.francetvinfo.fr/monde/usa/presidentielle/retrait-de-joe-biden/presidentielle-americaine-2024-emmanuel-macron-salue-le-courage-et-le-sens-du-devoir-de-joe-biden_6680886.html |access-date=September 11, 2024 |website=[[Franceinfo]] |language=fr-FR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=July 22, 2024 |title='Je mesure la gravité de ce moment pour vous' : la lettre d'Emmanuel Macron à Joe Biden après son retrait de la course présidentielle |url=https://www.lefigaro.fr/international/je-mesure-la-gravite-de-ce-moment-pour-vous-la-lettre-d-emmanuel-macron-a-joe-biden-apres-son-retrait-de-la-course-presidentielle-20240722 |access-date=September 11, 2024 |website=[[Le Figaro]] |language=fr |trans-title='I measure the gravity of this moment for you': Emmanuel Macron's letter to Joe Biden after his withdrawal from the presidential race}}</ref>

'''{{flag|Germany}}''': Chancellor [[Olaf Scholz]] posted a statement on [[Twitter]], stating "Joe Biden has achieved a great deal: for his country, for Europe, for the world... Thanks to him, transatlantic cooperation is close, [[NATO]] is strong and the USA is a good and reliable partner for us. His decision not to run again deserves recognition".<ref name="Reuters-2024" /><ref name="q282" />

'''{{flagcountry|Republic of Ireland}}''': In a statement, [[Taoiseach]] [[Simon Harris]] issued thanks to Biden, saying: "On behalf of the people and government of Ireland. I ... would like to thank you Mr President for your global leadership and your friendship as you make your announcement that you will not stand in the 2024 US Presidential election... Joe Biden, in all the offices he has held, has always been an unwavering voice and passionate worker for peace on the island of Ireland and our country owes him a great debt for this".<ref name="Reuters-2024" /> [[Tánaiste]] [[Micheál Martin]] said he heard of Biden's decision "with both sadness and admiration... This has no doubt been the toughest of calls, but one done, as ever, with dignity & class. I know that the people of Ireland will wish President Biden the very best".<ref name="q282" />

'''{{flag|Israel}}''': President [[Isaac Herzog]] thanked Biden "for his friendship and steadfast support for the Israeli people over his decades long career",<ref name="b913">{{cite web |agency=AFP – Agence France Presse |title=President Isaac Herzog Thanks Biden's 'Support For The Israeli People' |website=Barron's |date=July 21, 2024 |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/president-isaac-herzog-thanks-biden-s-support-for-the-israeli-people-1f3206ff |access-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722102913/https://www.barrons.com/news/president-isaac-herzog-thanks-biden-s-support-for-the-israeli-people-1f3206ff |url-status=live}}</ref> in a statement on social media,<ref name="r016">{{cite web |last=Horovitz |first=Michael |title=Israeli leaders thank Biden for 'steadfast support' after he quits presidential race |website=The Times of Israel |date=July 21, 2024 |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/israeli-officials-thank-biden-for-steadfast-support-after-he-quits-presidential-race/ |access-date=July 22, 2024}}</ref> continuing: "As the first US President to visit Israel in wartime, as a recipient of the Israeli [[President's Medal (Israel)|Presidential Medal of Honor]], and as a true ally of the Jewish people, he is a symbol of the unbreakable bond between our two peoples".<ref name="q282" /><ref name="VOA-2024" /> Defense Minister [[Yoav Gallant]] said: "Thank you President Joe Biden, for your unwavering support of Israel over the years. Your steadfast backing, especially during the war, has been invaluable. We are grateful for your leadership and friendship".<ref name="Reuters-2024" />

'''{{flag|Japan}}''': Prime Minister [[Fumio Kishida]] said that Biden made the best political decision and that, "Needless to say, the Japan–U.S. alliance is the pillar of Japan's diplomacy and security, so we'll closely watch the future developments".<ref name="Reuters-2024" />

'''{{flag|Mexico}}''': President [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] described Biden as a "good leader" with "very good results". He added: "Politically, he makes the decision not to participate in reelection, that is up to those who are members of the Democratic Party to decide, we are going to continue seeking to maintain a good relationship with the United States government".<ref>{{Cite web |date=July 22, 2024 |title=AMLO Habla de Renuncia de Biden a Candidatura en Elecciones de Estados Unidos 2024 |url=https://www.nmas.com.mx/nacional/politica/amlo-biden-renuncia-candidatura-elecciones-estados-unidos-2024/ |access-date=July 24, 2024 |website=N+ |language=es-MX |archive-date=July 24, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240724052744/https://www.nmas.com.mx/nacional/politica/amlo-biden-renuncia-candidatura-elecciones-estados-unidos-2024/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

'''{{flag|New Zealand}}''': Prime Minister [[Christopher Luxon]] stated: "President Biden has dedicated his life to public service, and that is something that deserves much respect. I thank the President for his leadership of the United States and his commitment to New Zealand. And I look forward to working with him for the remainder of his presidency".<ref name="Reuters-2024" /><ref name="q282" />

'''{{flag|Norway}}''': Prime Minister [[Jonas Gahr Støre]] told [[Reuters]]: "I respect President Joe Biden's decision not to run for re-election. He justifies the decision by saying that he wants to put the country before himself. That reasoning commands respect... Joe Biden has been one of America's most prominent politicians over several decades, and a president who has carried out several important reforms. I particularly commend him for his leadership in NATO and look forward to working with Biden as the president of the United States until the end of January".<ref name="Reuters-2024" />

'''{{flag|Philippines}}''': President [[Bongbong Marcos]] described Biden's withdrawal as "a demonstration of genuine statesmanship" and thanked him for his "constant and unwavering support for the Philippines in a delicate and difficult time".<ref>{{Cite tweet |number=1815240945685967288 |user=bongbongmarcos |title=President Biden's decision to withdraw from his candidacy is a demonstration of genuine statesmanship. We thank him for his constant and unwavering support for the Philippines in a delicate and difficult time. We wish him well for the rest of his presidency and for all his future endeavors. |first=Bongbong |last=Marcos |date=July 22, 2024 |access-date=July 22, 2024}}</ref>

'''{{flag|Poland}}''': Prime Minister [[Donald Tusk]] said on X: "Mr. President @JoeBiden, many times you have made difficult decisions that have made Poland, America, and the world safer, and democracy and freedom stronger. I know that you were guided by the same principles when announcing your latest decision. Perhaps the most difficult one in your life".<ref name="Reuters-2024" />

'''{{flag|Russia}}''': [[Presidential Administration of Russia|Kremlin]] spokesperson [[Dmitry Peskov]] stated that Russia was more focused on its goals in the ongoing [[Russian invasion of Ukraine|invasion of Ukraine]] than the results of the election.<ref name="Reuters-2024" /><ref name="q995" />

'''{{flag|Spain}}''': Prime Minister [[Pedro Sánchez]] on X stated: "All my admiration and recognition for the brave and dignified decision of the president @JoeBiden. Thanks to its determination and leadership, the US overcame the economic crisis after the pandemic and the serious assault on the Capitol and has been exemplary in its support for Ukraine in the face of [[Putin]]'s Russian aggression. A great gesture from a great president who has always fought for democracy and freedom".<ref name="Reuters-2024" />

'''{{flag|Ukraine}}''': President [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]] expressed gratitude on behalf of Ukraine for Biden's "unwavering support for Ukraine's fight for freedom", and that "[m]any strong decisions have been made in recent years and they will be remembered as bold steps taken by President Biden in response to challenging times. And we respect today's tough but strong decision."<ref>{{cite web |last=Gualtieri |first=Allison Elyse |title=Foreign leaders react to Biden's decision not to seek reelection |website=CBS News |date=July 21, 2024 |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/foreign-leaders-react-to-biden-withdrawal-starmer-tusk-harris-herzog/ |access-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722050328/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/foreign-leaders-react-to-biden-withdrawal-starmer-tusk-harris-herzog/ |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="q995">{{cite web |title=World leaders react to Biden dropping out of US election race |website=Al Jazeera |date=July 22, 2024 |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/22/world-leaders-react-to-biden-dropping-out-of-us-presidential-race |access-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722034645/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/22/world-leaders-react-to-biden-dropping-out-of-us-presidential-race |url-status=live}}</ref>

'''{{flag|United Kingdom}}''': Prime Minister Sir [[Keir Starmer]] published a statement on Twitter, saying that he respects Biden's decision to drop out, and looks forward to working with him during the remainder of his presidency.<ref>{{Cite tweet |number=1815112700919255318 |user=Keir_Starmer |title=I respect President Biden's decision and I look forward to us working together during the remainder of his presidency. I know that, as he has done throughout his remarkable career, he will have made his decision based on what he believes is best for the American people. |first=Keir |last=Starmer |date=July 22, 2024 |access-date=July 22, 2024}}</ref> Leader of the Opposition and former Prime Minister [[Rishi Sunak]] also remarked on Biden's accomplishments and wished him well.<ref>{{Cite tweet |number=1815108746957185070 |user=RishiSunak |title=Working with @JoeBiden, I saw firsthand his love for America and dedication to service. Our partnership has led to significant achievements, including AUKUS, steadfast support for Israel and joint efforts in defending our people from Houthi threats. I wish him all the best. |first=Rishi |last=Sunak |date=July 22, 2024 |access-date=July 22, 2024}}</ref>

'''{{flag|Venezuela|state}}''': President [[Nicolás Maduro]] said at a campaign event that Biden "made the most sensible and correct decision ... He prioritized his family and his health. He realized that at that age and with weakened health he could not assume the reins of his country, let alone a presidential candidacy".<ref name="Reuters-2024" />

title: Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election
deleted: ==Political responses==
===Democratic Party===
{{See also|List of Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign endorsements}}

Former presidents [[Bill Clinton]] and [[Barack Obama]] praised Biden's work as president, with Obama writing that "Joe Biden has been one of America's most consequential presidents" and that Biden "wouldn't make this decision unless he believed it was right for America".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Obama |first1=Barack |title=Bill and Hillary Clinton Endorse Kamala Harris |url=https://barackobama.medium.com/my-statement-on-president-bidens-announcement-1eb78b3ba3fc |website=Medium |access-date=July 21, 2024 |date=July 21, 2024 |archive-date=July 21, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240721195230/https://barackobama.medium.com/my-statement-on-president-bidens-announcement-1eb78b3ba3fc |url-status=live}}</ref> Many Democrats praised Biden's decision as "selfless", such as South Carolina Congressman [[Jim Clyburn]], Obama advisor [[David Axelrod (political consultant)|David Axelrod]], and Ohio Congressman [[Greg Landsman]], with Senate Majority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] writing that Biden "once again put his country, his party, and our future first" over himself.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Groves |first1=Stephen |title=Democrats hail Biden's decision to not seek reelection as selfless. Republicans urge him to resign |url=https://apnews.com/article/biden-withdraws-reaction-republicans-democrats-2a0a80121ef1b09a16a88cba6af6f90b |website=[[Associated Press]] |access-date=July 21, 2024 |date=July 21, 2024 |archive-date=July 21, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240721194600/https://apnews.com/article/biden-withdraws-reaction-republicans-democrats-2a0a80121ef1b09a16a88cba6af6f90b |url-status=live}}</ref> Former Secretary of State and presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] did the same and endorsed Harris.<ref name="MediaiteClinton">{{cite web |last1=Rumpf |first1=Sarah |title=My Statement on President Biden's Announcement |url=https://www.mediaite.com/biden/bill-and-hillary-clinton-endorse-kamala-harris-vow-to-do-whatever-we-can-to-support-her/ |website=Mediaite |access-date=July 21, 2024 |date=July 21, 2024 |archive-date=July 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240722110817/https://www.mediaite.com/biden/bill-and-hillary-clinton-endorse-kamala-harris-vow-to-do-whatever-we-can-to-support-her/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Trump campaign===

Following the announcement of Biden's withdrawal, Trump released a statement on [[Truth Social]], his social media platform, arguing that his former opponent "was not fit to run for President, and is certainly not fit to serve", calling him "the worst president, by far, in the history of our nation".<ref name="Lash 2024">{{cite news |last1=Lash |first1=Jolie |title='Worst president': Donald Trump reacts to President Joe Biden dropping out of 2024 election |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-reacts-president-joe-biden-dropping-2024/story?id=112143944 |access-date=July 21, 2024 |publisher=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |date=July 21, 2024 |ref=Lash 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240721194327/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-reacts-president-joe-biden-dropping-2024/story?id=112143944 |archive-date=July 21, 2024 |url-status=live}}</ref> Trump's [[Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign|re-election campaign]] had prepared opposition research dossiers on Kamala Harris and [[Pennsylvania]] governor [[Josh Shapiro]], who were viewed as a potential replacement ticket for Biden should he withdraw. The campaign intended to release messaging critical of Harris at the [[2024 Republican National Convention]], but ultimately decided against it.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/20/us/politics/trump-harris-strategy.html |title=Trump Campaign Prepares Attack Plan for Harris in Case Biden Withdraws |date=July 20, 2024 |last1=Haberman |first1=Maggie |last2=Swan |first2=Jonathan |author-link1=Maggie Haberman |author-link2=Jonathan Swan |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=July 20, 2024 |url-access=limited}}</ref>

Trump complained about Biden's withdrawal in a July 21 Truth Social post and requested that the Republican Party should be reimbursed for the money they spent campaigning against Biden.<ref name="2024-07-26 Washington Post: Svitek">{{cite news |last1=Svitek |first1=Patrick |date=July 26, 2024 |title=Biden is no longer running, but Republican attacks continue |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/07/26/trump-biden-continued-focus/ |url-status=live |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |language=en |issn=0190-8286 |oclc=2269358 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240727004147/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/07/26/trump-biden-continued-focus/ |archive-date=July 27, 2024 |access-date=July 28, 2024 |url-access=limited |quote=Former president Donald Trump and his allies spent years building up to a 2024 election effort centered on Biden. Now they have to recalibrate.}}</ref> Trump also compared the Democratic Party's support of replacing Biden to a "[[coup]]".<ref name="2024-07-26 Washington Post: Knowles, Meckler & Rozsa">{{cite news |last1=Knowles |first1=Hannah |last2=Meckler |first2=Laura |last3=Rozsa |first3=Lori |date=July 26, 2024 |title=Trump calls Harris a 'bum,' complains about Biden's withdrawal |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/07/26/trump-turning-point-speech-vance/ |url-status=live |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |language=en |location=[[West Palm Beach, Florida]] |issn=0190-8286 |oclc=2269358 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240727082108/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/07/26/trump-turning-point-speech-vance/ |archive-date=July 27, 2024 |access-date=July 28, 2024 |url-access=limited |quote=The former president urged attendees at a faith-themed event to vote, promising that in four years, 'we'll have it fixed so good you're not going to have to vote.'}}</ref> Trump's language of "coup" was widely imitated by other Republican politicians and strategists<ref name="2024-07-24 New York Times">{{cite news |last1=Yourish |first1=Karen |last2=Gamio |first2=Lazaro |date=July 24, 2024 |title='Coup' and 'Cover-Up': How the G.O.P. Is Reacting to the Harris Candidacy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/07/24/us/politics/harris-biden-republican-reactions.html |url-status=live |work=[[The New York Times]] |language=en |issn=1553-8095 |oclc=1645522 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240727173918/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/07/24/us/politics/harris-biden-republican-reactions.html |archive-date=July 27, 2024 |access-date=July 28, 2024 |url-access=limited}}</ref> and in an op-ed by [[Josh Hammer]], a senior editor of ''[[Newsweek]]''.<ref name="2024-07-26 Newsweek">{{cite news |last1=Hammer |first1=Josh |author-link1=Josh Hammer |date=July 26, 2024 |title=The Bloodless Coup of Joe Biden Will Not Work Out Well for Democrats |url=https://www.newsweek.com/bloodless-coup-joe-biden-will-not-work-out-well-democrats-opinion-1930493 |url-status=live |work=[[Newsweek]] |language=en |issn=0028-9604 |oclc=818916146 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240727235626/https://www.newsweek.com/bloodless-coup-joe-biden-will-not-work-out-well-democrats-opinion-1930493 |archive-date=July 27, 2024 |access-date=July 28, 2024}}</ref>

title: Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election
Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election
deleted: ==Notes==
{{Notelist}}

title: Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election
deleted: On July 18, ''[[Axios (website)|Axios]]'' reported that top Democrats believed Biden would exit the election, citing pressure from Jeffries and Schumer, internal polling, and criticism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.axios.com/2024/07/18/president-biden-drop-out-election-democrats |title=Top Dems now believe Biden will exit |date=July 18, 2024|last1=VandeHei |first1=Jim |last2=Allen |first2=Mike |author-link1=Jim VandeHei |author-link2=Michael Allen (journalist) |work=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |access-date=July 18, 2024}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported that day that Biden was considering ending his campaign.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/18/us/politics/biden-election-drop-out.html|title=People Close to Biden Say He Appears to Accept He May Have to Leave the Race |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 18, 2024 |archive-date=July 19, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240719063616/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/18/us/politics/biden-election-drop-out.html |url-status=live |last1=Shear|first1=Michael D. |last2=Baker|first2=Peter|last3=Rogers|first3=Katie|date=July 18, 2024 }}</ref>
